body: equals/hashCode are missing in search sort specs. It was just like that before this PR but it would be good to fix it here altogether.
:+1: it would be good to append PR number in commit message to make it simple to track issues.
@drcrallen Changed to throw ISE instead of returning null or NaN for count ==0 case.

This repo contains code to reproduce the issue:
https://github.com/boneill42/druid-ingestion

RE: this topic
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/In8I20MElGk

Hi,
If I can put a little of clue here, refering to the following would be helpful. 
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexIO.java#L607
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexMergerV9.java#L277

When a realtime index is persisted into a disk(and handed-off to a historical node), a dimension whose dictionary is empty is to be skipped.

Thank you.

@drcrallen i think the implementation assumes that updates/deletes of lookup is done only from the coordinator ? if true, is it a serious limitation i guess. We can do it in a way that first you pull all the known lookup from nodes and then compare it to coordinator view.

@b-slim yes. the coordinator coordinates the state of lookups in the cluster.

Why is that a limitation?

@binlijin I'm wondering if instead of adding a new type of partitioning we could extend the existing "hashed" type to support an arbitrary number of dimensions. I think it would also help reduce the confusion around the different partitioning schemes.
@drcrallen i know this is a complicated problem, can you first describe how you are doing the distributed coordination ? And let's start from there.

@navis agree that Sequences are very confusing and very hard to debug, and I think @cheddar(who first created them) does as well

We should have a discussion about what they could be replaced with at some point as I think there will be performance implications of just using iterables
@b-slim I'll writeup some more info in lookups.md on how it is propagated around.
Closing this and reviewing in #2601

@xvrl read #2586 before commenting here please

@binlijin can you add a README to the module? Something to help explain how to do the distinct count and also what to watch out for. If you guys use this in production, can you also note it is used in production in the README?

thanks for that pointer...
Interestingly enough, when the IndexIO task runs, it sees a cardinality of 4.  (which appears to include the null value)  

``` shell
Starting dimension[products] with cardinality[4]
```

Looking at the code...
We spin through the multi-values here:
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexIO.java#L622

Then do some null checking here?
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexIO.java#L630

RE: naming convention

If the description by Chan, et al. is mostly just copying from Youngs & Cramer, an they post the original implementation of the algorithm, then the scientifically correct name would be YoungsCramerVariance.
@himanshug just a few minor comments for conciseness, :+1: once those are addressed.

@navis can you split the changes to core druid (druid.processing) into its own PR so they can be explained and ensured to have proper testing around them?

This PR could then be the hive variance extension with only minimal or no changes to druid core.

@fjy @xvrl @navis the test names i used were to make the point of what was failing, I agree that names of methods should be adjusted to be more meaningful.

I agree with @drcrallen about exploring Streams as and when we move to Java8. I don't think iterables would support continuations the way Sequence does.
@xvrl made updates to address all comments.

:+1:  
minor: any reason we are keeping the duplicate jars in druid-examples and druid-cloudfiles-extensions?
@guobingkun Good question. My understanding is the examples is supposed to contain the jars (please correct if this is wrong) and the cloudfiles explicitly needs guava3 for something (I didn't dig)

@drcrallen I think, in this case, its fine to keep druid-core changes in the same PR which are needed to support the feature implemented by this PR or else its kinda hard to see why a particular core change was made. both changes needs to be reviewed together.
@himanshug any other comments?

navis : How about hiveVariance instead of ChanGolubLeVequeVariance?
i think we shouldn't use "hive" here as hive implementation of variance might change to something else in future but this implementation would stay to whatever algorithm it was using before.

@drcrallen @fjy @himanshug the PR is reviewable. Updated the top level comment to reflect the state of latest changes. @drcrallen using annotation based resource filtering for performing access checks.

I'm opening this PR now to cut down the size of that later patch, for easier review.

@xvrl see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2611

General comments:
- Approach is fine _IF_ this is a path that is desired to go. An alternative approach would be to have a static config and have the node read from that static config independent of the central config management (which is essentially what this PR does)
- https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2517#issuecomment-188424545 is still not adressed
- Package refactor is good
- Needs more clarification and **tests** around handling error cases (file corruption or failure to write to disk).
- Suggest moving from `List<LookupBean>` to `Map<String, LookupExtractorFactory>`

> Approach is fine IF this is a path that is desired to go. An alternative approach would be to have a static config and have the node read from that static config independent of the central config management (which is essentially what this PR does)

Talked to @cheddar about that and we think that the best way to go is to avoid the static path since it will introduce the case where after restart the old config is out of synch. But as you said it is basically the same thing.

>  #2517 (comment) is still not adressed

This will be manage by PR https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1576/. In my opinion coordinator will have a list of to drop and try to re send the drop request if the current diff show it is still there. That's why i think we should not compare to prior but the the actual view.

> Needs more clarification and tests around handling error cases (file corruption or failure to write to disk).

Sure Will do
@fjy ok, it's ready.

:+1: because I am refactoring extensions and we're moving towards being extremely lenient in community extensions vs core extensions to speed up how fast code gets in.

@navis I just noticed the thread in #2473 :(
@fjy can your reword your commit message to include some meaningful information? Agree with @gianm it would have been nicer to keep the formatting changes in a separate commit to make it cleaner.

:+1:

aside: I'm ok with making the kafka-eight-simpleConsumer extension a community rather than core extension, but wonder if anyone from y! feels that it should be core extension? (in other words: would someone like to sign up for maintaining & supporting it)
@navis @xvrl can we backport this to 0.9.0?

@navis, @fjy, IMO the spirit behind this PR (and #2473) is important enough to get into core, so I would rather see it there than in an extension.
- it's good to be able to filter with ops other than =, without using JS
- it's good for ops like > and < to take advantage of sortedness of the bitmap indexes (bound filter currently in core does not do this)

Would it make sense to address these by modifying the BoundFilter in these ways?
- make it _not_ a DimensionPredicateFilter but instead do its own thing
- have it take advantage of sortedness when possible (I think this is possible when `alphaNumeric` is false)
:+1: after travis

Just signed the CLA, thank you @b-slim and @fjy .
@drcrallen thanks for the review, i have addressed all the comments, please take a look.

@sirpkt I believe adding those shorthands might cause a lot of confusion, PeriodGranularity depends on the timezone of the server, but the existing shorthands are all UTC. Even though it is currently a requirement to run Druid with UTC timezone, we would like to lift this restriction in the future.
@gianm since you have a fix, do you mind submitting a PR?

Tranquility does work in non-UTC timezones, what it took to get there was,
- replacing all instances of `new DateTime(x)` with `new DateTime(x, ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` or `new DateTime(x).withChronology(ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` (depending on whether you want to parse strings in UTC or in the user's timezone)
- replacing all instances of `new Interval(long, long)` with `new Interval(long, long, ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)`
- replacing all instances of `new Interval(string)` with `new Interval(string, ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` or `new DateTime(x).withChronology(ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` (depending on whether you want to parse strings in UTC or in the user's timezone)
- call `.withChronology(ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` on DateTimes received from "outside"
- call `.withChronology(ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC)` on Intervals received from "outside"
re: "depending on whether you want to parse strings in UTC or in the user's timezone" IMO it would be better to parse strings in the user's timezone, so the latter form probably makes more sense.

@xvrl ah, I don't have a fix, I was just pointing out that the line numbers in the stack trace in my report doesn't match base Druid (we pulled an unrelated patch to that file back from master and that moved some lines around).

@gianm had some comments but overall looks good and from what I see this PR does not change  anything in RealtimeIndexTask  so it should have no impact on existing ingestion mechanism.

regarding the discussion points..
1) I think we can update RealtimePlumber  at some point if/when possible.
2) I'm not sure if we need to update IndexGeneratorReducer with this.
@b-slim Addressed comments
Agree with @gianm that we should always interpret strings in the user's timezone whenever possible (unless they already specify a time zone of course)
I filed https://github.com/metamx/java-util/pull/44 to hopefully make this less of an issue sometime in the future
:+1: any reason we are not including in 0.9.0?
@xvrl just because 0.9.0 is late in its cycle, and this has been a bug for a long time rather than a recent regression. I can backport it if people think that's worth it though.

@himanshug Can you add some comments to GroupByQueryQueryToolChest that calls attention to the optimization being made? 

:+1: aside from that
@xvrl I understand what you mean. Then, how about introducing system wide configuration parameter to indicate default timezone?

@sirpkt how about instead we make the shorthands always UTC for now? We can always introduce a configuration later. Introducing a config now is not going to be of any use until we resolve the other issues.
@navis Thnks. It will be very helpful for someone who wants to implement BI like tool.

As I know, PeriodGranularity with null timezone use UTC.
Do you mean explicit use of timezone `ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC()` in PeriodGranularity?
